awd_abstract_narration:
With support from Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods  (CTMC) program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Krzysztof Szalewicz of University of Delaware is performing quantum-mechanical investigations of clusters of molecules, molecular condensed phases, and biomolecular systems. The properties of such systems are governed by intermolecular (van der Waals) forces: depending on the distance between two molecules, they will either attract or repel each other, a physical law that Richard Feynman considered to be the biggest finding of humanity. Szalewicz and coworkers have developed methods for computing intermolecular forces that are not only among the most accurate and computationally efficient ones, but also provide researchers with a unique ability to interpret properties dependent on intermolecular forces in terms of the four fundamental physical mechanisms: the electrostatic, exchange-repulsion, polarization, and dispersion interactions. Since direct quantum-mechanical calculations are limited to molecular assemblies with a hundred or so atoms, Szalewicz’s group will develop machine-learning methods of extrapolating quantum results to arbitrary-size systems. The importance of this work stems from its ability to predict properties of matter from first principles, i.e., deriving them from equations of quantum mechanics, for arbitrary molecular materials. One example are reliable predictions of crystal structures. Computational design of crystals is of significant importance for pharmaceutical, agrochemical, semiconductor, and energetic materials industries.  The fundamental research on intermolecular forces being conducted here has the potential for broad scientific impact across a wide array of fields from materials science to  biomolecular, and atmospheric science, to molecular spectroscopy and astrophysics. Broader impacts of this activity include training of graduate students and postdoctoral associates with diverse backgrounds, extensive collaborations with other research groups, organization of conferences and workshops that will disseminate knowledge, participation in award committees and in activities of an international academia, and developments of free software to be used by other researchers.

Under this ward, the Szalewicz group is developing and utilizing symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT) based on monomers described by density-functional theory (DFT), an approach denoted as SAPT(DFT). Machine-learning methods for the generation of force fields derived from SAPT(DFT) calculations will be extended to enable treatment of molecules with soft internal degrees of freedom. These force fields will be used for several systems of current experimental, observational, or technological interest, in particular for predictions of crystal structures from first principles, including difficult cases with polymorphism related to varying conformations of monomers. Other developments of theory will include work on nonlocal-correlation DFT methods that can reliably predict dispersion energies, improved DFT methods that can be paired with accurate dispersion energies, extensions of machine-learning force-field generation methods to three-body nonadditive interactions, and universal force fields based on ab initio computed monomer properties, a step in the direction of physics-based biomolecular force fields. These studies are expected to advance knowledge of the field of intermolecular interactions and to have promise for transformative changes in electronic structure methods, in force-field development techniques, and in crystal structure predictions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Theoretical and computational investigations of molecular clusters and molecular condensed phases have been performed. Properties of such systems depend on weak interactions between molecules, called intermolecular interactions, van der Waals interactions, or noncovalent interactions. They are ‘weak’ since their energies are least an order of magnitude smaller than the energies of chemical bonds. The intermolecular interaction energies can be computed using ab initio electronic structure methods for approximately solving the equations of quantum mechanics. The words ab initio indicate that such electronic structure methods do not use any results from experimental observations. Since quantum calculations are expensive, in order to investigate molecular clusters and molecular condensed phases, the results of such calculations—performed for selected configurations of a cluster—are often fitted by fairly simple analytic functions called force fields (FFs) or potential energy surfaces (PESs). FFs describe intermolecular interactions between constituent molecules for an arbitrary configuration of the investigated system.  Once FFs of sufficiently high-accuracy are known, one can predict essentially all properties of molecular clusters and molecular condensed phases.

Interaction energies can be in particular computed using an ab initio method called symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT), co-developed by our group. In contrast to other methods used to determine interaction energies, SAPT computes them directly, starting from isolated molecules and expanding the interaction energy in powers of the operator collecting all interactions of particles of a molecule with those of the interacting partner. SAPT is formally an exact theory and in practice its accuracy is similar to the coupled cluster method with single, double, and noniterative triple excitations, CCSD(T). SAPT provides a unique ability to interpret properties dependent on intermolecular forces in terms of the four fundamental physical mechanisms that lead to the electrostatic, exchange, induction, and dispersion contributions to the interaction energies. A recent paper from our group presented rigorous analysis of these physical components that follows directly from SAPT equations, rather than from heuristic arguments. Physical interpretations are essential parts of most publications from our group.

Physics-based FFs fitted to SAPT’s ab initio interaction energies, aiFFs, provide a new route to first-principles simulations of matter, and may replace commonly used empirical FFs, i.e., FFs fitted to results of experiments. This will allow one to simulate matter entirely from first principles, which is currently possible only for selected small systems and involves significant human effort in each case. An important step in this direction has been made in the field of crystal structure predictions (CSPs). Such predictions are a particularly demanding task for theory due to the huge configuration space of plausible polymorphs that has to be sampled. The use of a new efficient version of SAPT codes and of our codes for automatic fitting of aiFFs, called autoPES, allows one to perform entirely first-principles, inexpensive, and reliable CSPs. Our method, named aiFF@CSPs, resulted in the experimental crystal ranked as number one for all crystals to which it was applied. The method has the potential of assisting several industries in search for new crystalline materials, for example, predicting all possible polymorphic forms of a drug.

The current aiFF@CSPs method is limited to rigid monomers, i.e., to molecules that in a crystal environment deform only negligibly from their gas-phase equilibrium structures. While there are numerous such cases, a lot of crystals are built from flexible monomers, i.e., molecules that have soft degrees of freedom, mainly torsions around some dihedral angles.  For such monomers, one has to account for changes of intramonomer energies during the minimization of crystal lattice energy, therefore, one has to know intramonomer FFs.  We have been working on extending aiFF@CSPs to such molecules.  As the first step, we demonstrated that the available empirical intramonomer FFs have essentially zero predictive power, therefore such FFs have to be reparametrized by fitting to to ab initio data.  Although there are several programs available for performing such reparametrization, they produce FFs that are still not accurate enough for reliable CSPs, although the predictions are improved relatively to the use of empirical FFs:  for several crystals with flexible monomers, our CSPs resulted in the experimental polymorph ranked as number one.  We adopted the best performing program and are now in the process of coding the optimization of the so-called nonbonded parameters, i.e., parameters in the terms acting only between remote atoms in each monomer.  Apparently and somewhat surprisingly, none of the available codes includes such optimizations.
